subject: Medicine
title: Myelin: The Speed Booster
description: A short lesson to help you apply Myelin: The Speed Booster.

hook.text: Nerve signals in a myelinated fiber travel at 120 meters per second. Without myelin, they crawl at 2.

buildup.text: Myelin is a fatty sheath that wraps around axons, insulating them like rubber around an electrical wire.

discovery.text: It speeds up signal transmission by forcing impulses to jump between gaps in the sheath called nodes.

twist.text: Multiple sclerosis destroys myelin. As the insulation breaks down, nerve signals slow, scramble, or stop.

climax.text: Myelin continues forming into your late twentiesâ€”which is why teen brains process information differently.

punchline.text: Speed of thought depends on the insulation.

quiz.question: What happens when myelin is destroyed, as in multiple sclerosis?
options: Nerve signals slow down, scramble, or stop entirely
The brain creates new neurons to compensate
